text.p: These are the highlights of stories in Serbian and Montenegrin press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified them nor does it vouch for their accuracy.
-- S E R B I A --
POLITIKA

- Newly appointed Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic said Yugoslavia must be peaceful, free and independent. We will intitiate huge project and process of material and spiritual renewal and reforms of society, he said after beeing sworn in.

- Milosevic received federal Prime Minister Radoje Kontic, Serbian acting and Montenegrin presidents Dragan Tomic and Momir Bulatovic and expressed hope that joint activities would secure strenghtening of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
- Russian Federation ambassador to Belgrade Yuri Kotov said Russia does not recognise the outer wall of sanctions.
- Serbian oil company NIS Jugopetrol said price of fuel will not increase.
- Serbian electric power company EPS needs one billion dinars to overhaul its capacities. EPS outstanding claims stand at 2.2 billion dinars.
- Almost 1.5 tonnes of '97 wheat crop has already been stored in silos of flour mills' and agricultural producers' organisations.
- Businessmen expect rise in production and increase of utilisation of capacities, said Belgrade based Economics Institute in its latest monthly report.
NASA BORBA

- Presidental elections in Serbia will be held on September 21 and the SPS presidental candidate will be known on Friday, said vice-president of the ruling Socialist Party of Serbia. He said former Yugoslav president Zoran Lilic would be an excellent candidate.
- Protesters threw old shoes on Milosevic's car.
- The Democratic Party of Serbia forcast period of unstable authority.
- EPS expects 30 million German marks loan from the Serbian Development Fund for overhaul of its capacities.
- Serbian bakers demand bread price increase. If one kilo of wheat costs 1.10 dinars, price of flour should be two dinars per kilo and one 0.6 kilo loaf of bread three dinars, bakers said.

- Money supply M1 rose by 643 million dinars in last two months. Despite four months of monetary policy expansion, production is on decline, export stagnates and only wages are on rise, the Economics Institute said in its latest report.
- Serbian Minister for Information Radmila Milentijevic said the shutdown of local media has nothing to do with politics.
- Serbian Minister for Education Jovo Todorovic said money has been secured for teachers' April wages payout.
BORBA
- Serbian government and education, science and culture trade union agree on dynamics of payment of wages.
DANAS
- Socialist Party of Bosnian Serb republic says it has no confirmation about possible visit soon by new Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.
- Several hundreds of supporters and opponents of Milosevic exchange insults outside federal parliament during inauguration ceremony.

- The Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO) will not participate in republican presidential or parliamentary elections if local television stations continue to be shut down in towns where the opposition coalition Zajedno won in local elections last November, says SPO President Vuk Draskovic.
BLIC
- Yugoslav car manufacturer Zastava of Kragujevac ends talks with possible foreign partners. According to a report on the Internet, France's Peugeot says almost certain to enter deal with Zastava.
-- M O N T E N E G R O --
POBJEDA
- Montenegrin parliament speaker Svetozar Marovic called for republic's presidental elections on October 5. List of candidates to be submitted to republic's eelctoral comission by September 15.

- Montenegrin Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic said he would cooperate with Milosevic in accordance with the democrtatic rules and constitutional position envisaged for the federal president and Montenegrin prime minister.

- Posting Serbian customs officers and barriers in Prijepolje on the Serbian-Montenegrin border divides the federal market and opens way for confederation, said president of the Montenegrin Alliance of Independent Trade Unions Danilo Popovic.
- Vice-president of Italian Olivetti said the company excpected to start production in Montenegro soon.
- The first regional offices of a comission for Bosnian refugees' property issues will open in Podgorica and Herceg Novi on September 24. -- Belgrade Newsroom +381 11 311 4254
